title: Post‑tonsillectomy: What to expect (Days 1–7)
care_tips: Offer small, frequent sips of cool fluids
Soft foods as tolerated; avoid sharp, spicy, or hot foods
Use pain plan provided at discharge; never exceed labeled use
Keep child resting; quiet play is okay
red_flags: Bright‑red bleeding from mouth
Fever ≥ 39.0 °C or fever lasting > 2 days
Signs of dehydration (very dark urine, no tears, very sleepy)

title: Ear infection (Acute Otitis Media) at home
normal_symptoms: Ear pain that improves within 48–72 hours after start of treatment
care_tips: Follow the antibiotic plan exactly as prescribed if one was given
Use the provider‑approved pain plan for comfort
Keep the child hydrated; offer fluids often
red_flags: Ear swelling/redness spreading behind the ear
Fever ≥ 39.0 °C or not improving after 72 hours
Stiff neck, severe headache, or child very hard to wake

title: RSV or Bronchiolitis recovery at home
care_tips: Use nasal saline and gentle suction before feeds and sleep
Offer smaller, more frequent feeds to maintain hydration
Keep child upright after feeds when possible
Follow any inhaled treatments only as prescribed
red_flags: Fast breathing, ribs pulling in, pauses in breathing
Blue/gray lips or face
Fewer wet diapers than usual (possible dehydration)
references: CDC: RSV in infants and young children

title: Stomach bug (gastroenteritis): hydration and rest
care_tips: Small sips of oral rehydration solution; increase as tolerated
Avoid sugary drinks and undiluted juice early on
Re‑introduce simple foods when vomiting slows
Follow hand‑washing to prevent spread
red_flags: Vomiting that prevents keeping fluids down for 8 hours
Blood in stool or black stool
No urination for 8–12 hours or very dry mouth/eyes

title: Asthma flare: home monitoring after ED visit
normal_symptoms: Mild cough or wheeze that improves with the action plan
care_tips: Use inhalers only as in the written action plan
Spacer device improves delivery—use every time
Track symptoms and rescue inhaler use
Avoid known triggers (smoke, strong scents)
red_flags: Needing rescue inhaler more often than every 4 hours
Trouble speaking full sentences, ribs pulling in
Bluish lips or fingertips—seek urgent care
references: AAP: Asthma action plans for children

title: Cast care for minor arm fracture
care_tips: Keep the cast dry; use a cover for bathing
Elevate the arm in the first 2 days to reduce swelling
Do not insert objects under the cast; call if very itchy
red_flags: Fingers very cold/blue, severe pain, numbness/tingling
Cracked, soggy, or foul‑smelling cast

title: Stitches or skin glue: keeping wounds clean
normal_symptoms: Mild redness right at the edges
care_tips: Keep area clean and dry; follow instructions for bathing
Do not pick at glue or scabs; protect during play
Use sunscreen after healing to reduce scarring
red_flags: Spreading redness, thick yellow/green drainage, foul smell
Fever or increasing pain at the site
Edges opening or heavy bleeding

title: Pneumonia: antibiotics and rest at home
care_tips: Give antibiotics exactly as prescribed; do not stop early
Offer fluids regularly and allow extra rest
Return to school when fever‑free and energy improving
red_flags: Breathing faster or harder, ribs pulling in
Fever ≥ 39.0 °C after 48 hours of antibiotics
Lips turning blue/gray—call emergency services

title: Appendectomy: first week at home
care_tips: Keep incision sites clean and dry; follow dressing guidance
Short walks a few times per day; avoid contact sports
Pain plan as prescribed; avoid constipation (fiber & fluids)
red_flags: Fever ≥ 39.0 °C or worsening belly pain
Redness spreading far beyond incision or pus drainage
Vomiting that prevents fluids or meds

title: Seasonal flu: comfort and monitoring
normal_symptoms: Fever and body aches for 2–3 days
Cough and tiredness up to a week
care_tips: Fluids and rest; return to normal activity gradually
Use only medications approved by the child’s provider
Keep child home until fever‑free for 24 hours without medicine
red_flags: Trouble breathing, chest pain, confusion
Dehydration: very dry mouth, no tears, no urination for 8–12h
Fever lasting > 3 days or returning after improvement
